utterances: I wasn't even going to say that.

Well, I think what we need to understand, in this case with Venezuela, is the relationship between Hugo Chavez and Iran is very concerning.

A lot of people don't know, and I have Iranian sources that have told me that under Khatami, there was an arrangement between Venezuela and Iran to smuggle in Syrian and Iranian spies under the auspices of Venezuelan passports, because of how difficult that has become through other channels after 9/11.

Also, when Khatami visited Iran last year, Hugo Chavez chummed around with him, discussing how they were going to build a strong alliance against the United States, and that he expressed an interest in introducing nuclear elements through the help of Iran into Venezuela.

Now, these types of issues have been flying under the radar with the average American citizen, but the state department and the secretary of state, Condoleezza Rice, they understand the danger of having a Hugo Chavez/Iranian relationship in the Southern hemisphere.
And not only that, it's correct that there is a dramatic shift to the left, and there is a certain anti-American sentiment going on in Latin America, unlike we've seen in a long time.

And what the Americans are trying to do with issues like CAFTA, we're trying to maintain a certain amount of economic influence in the region, so that we have them on our side, because there's a shrinking cadre of American allies in Latin America.
All right.
Let me move us quickly, because we have an abbreviated roundtable today.

We're going to do a salute, in just a few moments, to Miles Davis and his induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, but what a lot of people are talking about, Pedro, is this fascination that America seems to have with the Sopranos, and in particular, minorities.
African-Americans, Latinos and the like, love this show.
And we've seen, historically, the love of gangsters.
While Tony has become the loveable gangster, is there any danger in blurring the lines here?
Tomorrow's Democratic presidential primary here in South Carolina is a crucial one for Senator John Edwards.
It's the state where he was born.
Edwards' message here has been especially geared towards poor and working-class South Carolinians.

And he might be resonating more with African-Americans in the state if he were not competing against an African-American candidate, Barack Obama, and Hillary Clinton, a woman with strong ties to black America.
I spoke with Edwards and asked what he plans to do after tomorrow if he doesn't win at least second place.

Oh, I'm in this for the long haul, and the causes that I'm engaged in, speaking for the people who don't have a voice, speaking for the uninsured, for people who live in poverty, for our veterans, for the men and women who are serving in Iraq, those are the causes of my life.
And they're not going away, and I'm in this for the long haul.
Now you've talked many times, including in this week's debate, about your father working in the mills.
You yourself have succeeded in making millions of dollars living a much wealthier lifestyle.
So when people think about their place in America, what obligation do voters in your income bracket have to pay their taxes and take action on behalf of poor and working-class people?
They have an obligation to do what I have done my whole life.
I came from a family that had nothing.
I worked hard all my life.
In fact, the way I made my living was representing the kind of people that I grew up with, people who didn't have much of anything, and fighting against very entrenched, powerful corporate interests.
And we were able to win and be successful.
I did well by doing good.
And what we have a responsibility to do is to make sure we don't pull the ladder out from behind us.
That everybody gets - in fact, it's the core reason that I am running for president is to make sure that everybody in this country gets the kind of chances and opportunities that I've had in my life.
That's what drives me every single day.
A lot of your supporters mention that you really have a commitment to ending poverty, but could there ever be an America with absolutely no poverty?
What would that country even look like?
It would be a country where everybody has real economic opportunity.
I mean, is there always going to be a circumstance where somebody could fall into poverty?
Of course.
I mean, because that's the real world.
But if we do the things we need to do, we wouldn't have the kind of systematic, endemic poverty we have in America.
I mean, we have 37 million people, which is roughly the population of California, who live in poverty every day in this country.
It's not a small number.
And we are the richest, most prosperous nation on the planet, and there are lots of things that we need to do.
We need to raise the minimum wage.
We need universal health care, make it easier for kids to go to college.
We need to strengthen the right of unions to organize, expand the earned income tax credit.
I mean, there is a whole group of things that need to be done to address poverty in a really serious way.
We had on Shun Griffin.
He's a sophomore at Furman University in Greenville, South Carolina.

He's a black man and he admitted, despite the fact that he's out there for you 110 percent, that sometimes people give him flak for being a black man who supports a white male candidate in a race with a black man and a white woman.
So do you worry that some of the people who might otherwise support your message are taking race and gender into account in a way that doesn't favor you?
No, what I worry about is whether I am being heard.

I think when - Martin Luther King III just put out a statement a couple of days ago saying that the things that I've been driving in this entire campaign and in my life, in which you and I have spoken about already, but the problem we have is being heard through the glitz and glamour of Senator Obama and Senator Clinton's campaign and the money.
They both have over $100 million of campaign money.
That's the struggle that we have.
When I get heard, it works.
And it works every single time.
Are you running out of money?
No, well, actually, here's the amazing thing that's happened here in the last - since the first of January.
We've raised record amounts online, on the Internet and as a result, we have - we - the money won't be the issue.
We have plenty of money.
Now, you've mentioned the glitz and glamour of the Clinton and Obama campaigns.
You have your own celebrity supporters like Danny Glover.
Senator Obama brought out Chris Tucker and Kerry Washington.
And there've been a lot of celebrities in this state.
Danny Glover is out here for you.
How important is celebrity, should it be important?
Nobody should decide who to vote on based on who a celebrity is for.
And I don't think - by the way, I don't think this is news to anybody.
Your listeners think exactly the same thing.
They're not going to decide to vote for somebody because they have a celebrity supporting them.
They're going to decide to vote for them because they believe they will be the best president.
Do you ever feel pressure to get into the mix and sling some harder punches in a time where Senators Clinton and Obama seem to be going at each other and getting headlines for it?
Do you ever think, I've got to put some muscle into this.
And maybe I need to go after both of them?
Oh no. I got plenty of muscle in this.
My muscle is different than what you see from the two of them.
What we saw in the debate at Myrtle Beach on CNN on Monday night was a lot of petty bickering and personal in-fighting between the two of them.
And I was glad to be able to be the grown-up on the stage, because this is not about any of us personally.
And all that bickering is not going to get a single child health care, it's not going to lift a single American out of poverty, it's not going to create a single job.
Come on now.
So why do we explain it away, but then we turn around on one side...
But here's the...
...and we complain...
Well, that's a pleasure.

And as long as we're talking about the differences that we have on issues, and we have differences on issues, you know, on health care, exactly what we do to end the war, how do we create jobs and end global poverty - I mean, excuse me, attack global warming.
I mean, we have differences on these substantive issues.
But when it gets to the level of petty bickering and personal attacks, this is not helping anybody.
And that's my view about it and I have no intention of engaging in it.
You know, we're here in the South.
You're a native Southerner.
This part of the country is a place where history has been written and rewritten, depending on who you consider the victor.
And right now there's this tussle over Ben Tillman, ""Pitchfork Ben,"" a South Carolina governor and U.S.
senator in the late 19th century who supported lynching.
How do you think - there's a question of whether or not to take down a statue of him.
But how do you think Southern history, including the history of race relations should be featured, focused on, talked about by people like yourself who have power?
Well, I can tell you my own perspective.
I grew up in the South, in South Carolina, Georgia and North Carolina, in the '50s and '60s.
I saw the segregated South during my youth, and I saw the South transition during the civil rights movement.
This - I take it as a huge personal cause to continue the march to equality in this country.

And I think having lived through it, and not having seen it on television or read about it in a book, but having actually lived through the loss of lives, the extraordinary sacrifice of men and women who literally put their lives on the line to move this country toward civil rights and toward equality.
I feel like I carry a huge responsibility and a huge burden.
I said this in the debate and I believe it.
You know, we can put our head against the wall and pretend the history doesn't exist.
But the reality is, we had decades of slavery, followed by decades of segregation, followed by decades of discrimination, and some of that discrimination still continues today.
And I think people like me, who have lived through a lot of this, carry an enormous responsibility to continue the march toward equality in this country.
Senator Edwards, thank you so much for talking to us.
Wonderful to be with you.
Senator John Edwards is making his second run for the White House.
He joined us by phone while on the road somewhere between Anderson and Seneca, South Carolina.

Let's talk some more about the hat.
You know which one I'm talking about - the red Make America Great Again hat, the MAGA hat.
Why is the hat such a big deal?
Washington Post fashion and culture critic Robin Givhan has been thinking about that.
And she's with us now in our studios in Washington, D.C.
Welcome back.
Thanks so much for joining us.
Thank you.
You wrote a whole column about the MAGA hat.
You said that the Make America Great Again hat is not a statement of policy anymore.
It's a declaration of identity.
So, first of all, why do you say that?
And what is that identity?
Well, I mean, I think the MAGA hat, you know, did start out as a - you know, as sort of innocuous political swag.
And then it came to represent, you know, the Trump administration, the Trump campaign.
And people who were wearing it I think were, at that point, focused on various policy ideas, whether it was tax cuts or a point of view when it comes to foreign policy or immigration.

But I think what happened is that the hat was essentially kidnapped, weaponized by Charlottesville and by white supremacists and by the violence that went on in some of those rallies by a minority of people at those rallies.
But that hat came to I think, in the broader culture, start to represent a lot of really dark forces.
And it has come to represent, also, this idea of making America great again as in, oh, it once was great in some distant past.
And things happened to make it less great.
So political figures have used fashion to make statements before, like Hillary Clinton had the blue pantsuits that then became the white pantsuits because that's something that the suffragists wore.
And even though Barack Obama wasn't really known for his fashion, I mean, there were symbols associated with him that people made into fashion.
Like, the Shepard Fairey ""Hope"" poster was a thing for a while...
Right.
Is it your contention that this is at a different level, it has some broader cultural meaning apart from the political figure itself?
Yeah.
I mean, I do think it's different from those things because - the groups and attitudes and sensibilities and moods that it's associated with.
And I think, you know, there is this notion that simply because you put on the hat means that, you know, you are all these terrible things.
And I don't necessarily think that is the case.
And I don't think most people presume that to be the case.

But I do think that there's this sense that if you put on that hat, you are knowingly shrouding yourself in something that has all of these dark connotations and, in knowingly doing that, that implies that you're OK with it.
Is that symbolism, in your view, equally understood by those who wear it and by those who receive it or see it?
Sometimes not, sometimes it does.
I mean, you know, I think, you know, you can look back in - at much darker periods in history, you know?
And there are those who might argue that, oh, I'm wearing this because I'm a history buff.
But the broader culture at large knows what it means, historically.
Well, you draw the analogy to the Confederate flag.
Right.
I mean, you say that - in your column, you say that to wear a MAGA hat is to wrap oneself in a Confederate flag, which you also see as a provocation.
Now, along those same lines, there are plenty of people who will say, no, it's not.
It's a reflection of history.
It's a reflection of Southern heritage.
It's not meant to be provocative or racist.
And to that, would you say, are these people just not willing to be honest about what they're trying to say?
